prompt.p: In some instances, genetic variation confers protection against endemic infections.
What genetic abnormality (polymorphism) provides some protection against certain types of malaria infection?

modalFeedback.p:
Option B (Sickle cell anaemia) is Correct. Sickle cell disease is an example of a single nucleotide polymorphism. Individuals with the abnormal sickle cell haemoglobin are protected from Plasmodium falciparum infection. Merozoites normally interact with red cells through two interactions that are dependent on P. falciparum erythrocyte membrane protein-1. These proteins are impaired in individuals with sickle cell haemoglobin, explaining why sickle cell disease has not been lost from the tropical world through natural selection.
Option A (Turner's syndrome) is Incorrect. Turner's syndrome is the result of the absence of one X chromosome (XO), not polymorphism.
Option C (Fragile X syndrome) is Incorrect. Fragile X syndrome is caused by single nucleotide polymorphism, where there are insertions of nucleotides in multiples of three. It does not protect against endemic infection.
Option D (Huntington's disease) is Incorrect. Huntington's disease is caused by triple nucleotide repeats in single nucleotide polymorphism.
Option E (Ankylosing spondylitis) is Incorrect. Ankylosing spondylitis patients express human lymphocyte antigen (HLA)-B27 genotype. The greatest single nucleotide polymorphism diversity is found on the HLA locus. Ankylosing spondylitis is not protective against endemic infection.
